name: Kepler-291
scenarioDescription:
The Kepler-291 Exoplanetary System

Kepler-291 is a star with 0.9770000000000001 times the mass of the Sun, and 1.02 times its radius. It is located 6145.99 light years away from the solar system.

Kepler-291 is known to have 2 exoplanets in orbit around it.

Kepler-291 b

Kepler-291 b was discovered by the Kepler observatory using the transit method. Its discovery was announced in 2014-03. Its semi-major axis is 0.05 astronomical units, as compared to Earth's which is 1 astronomical unit. It takes 3.55 Earth days to complete an orbit around its host star, Kepler-291.

The mass of Kepler-291 b is 6.13 times the mass of Earth. The radius of Kepler-291 b is 2.16 that of Earth. At 6.13 Earth masses, Kepler-291 b is a so called Super Earth. Super Earths could be terrestrial worlds like Earth, but they could also be ocean worlds or terrestrial worlds wrapped in a substantial atmosphere, in which case some refer to them as Mini Neptunes. No Super Earths are known to exist in our solar system, but if it exists, the so-called Planet Nine could very well be a super Earth, as it is hypothesized to have a mass between five and ten Earth masses.

Kepler-291 c

Kepler-291 c was discovered by the Kepler observatory using the transit method. Its discovery was announced in 2014-03. Its semi-major axis is 0.07 astronomical units, as compared to Earth's which is 1 astronomical unit. It takes 5.70 Earth days to complete an orbit around its host star, Kepler-291.

The mass of Kepler-291 c is 4.39 times the mass of Earth. The radius of Kepler-291 c is 1.88 that of Earth. At 4.39 Earth masses, Kepler-291 c is a so called Super Earth. Super Earths could be terrestrial worlds like Earth, but they could also be ocean worlds or terrestrial worlds wrapped in a substantial atmosphere, in which case some refer to them as Mini Neptunes. No Super Earths are known to exist in our solar system, but if it exists, the so-called Planet Nine could very well be a super Earth, as it is hypothesized to have a mass between five and ten Earth masses.
description: 3D visualisation and gravity simulation of the exoplanet system Kepler-291, which contains 2 planets and was discovered by Kepler.
